qas.question: What is the crucial advantage of four-rail system?
What danger can return currents cause?
How did return current effect water and gas in iron pipes?
How are stray earth currents kept to a manageable levels?
What insures minimal current leak during power rails instalation?

plausible_answers.text: neither running rail carries any current

qas.question: What is a key advantage to the fifth rail system?
What can happen if the tunnel segments are electrically bonded together?
What has a tendency to flow past nearby iron pipes forming the water and gas mains?
What has a naturally created earth point?
What does not have to be seated on stronger metal chairs?

context: The key advantage of the four-rail system is that <b5_0>neither <a0_0>running rail carries any current<b5_0/><a0_0/>. This scheme was introduced because of the problems of return currents, intended to be carried by the earthed (grounded) running rail, flowing through the iron tunnel linings instead. This can cause <a1_0><b6_0>electrolytic damage<a1_0/> and even arcing<b6_0/> if the tunnel segments are not electrically bonded together. The problem was exacerbated because <b7_0>the return current<b7_0/> also had a tendency to flow through nearby iron pipes forming the <a2_0>water and gas mains<a2_0/>. Some of these, particularly Victorian mains that predated London's underground railways, were not constructed to carry currents and had no adequate electrical bonding between pipe segments. The four-rail system solves the problem. Although <b8_0>the supply<b8_0/> has an artificially created earth point, this connection is derived <a3_0>by using resistors<a3_0/> which ensures that stray earth currents are kept to manageable levels. Power-only rails can be mounted on strongly insulating <a4_0>ceramic chairs<a4_0/> to minimise current leak, but this is not possible for <b9_0>running rails<b9_0/> which have to be seated on stronger metal chairs to carry the weight of trains. However, elastomeric rubber pads placed between the rails and chairs can now solve part of the problem by insulating the running rails from the current return should there be a leakage through the running rails.
